Aged head of the Corleone crime family, Vito Corleone has known peace and power through violence in his clandestine criminal dynasty. When fate intervenes and sends the family into turmoil, it is his most reluctant of sons who must take over the mantle of Godfather to not only keep his family alive but keep there power intact as well. One of the most acclaimed masterpiece's of film history The Godfather is a visually stunning, beautifully performed and expertly crafted film. Bringing its viewer into 1940's New York the viewer can't help but feel as though it was actually filmed within that period. Based off the acclaimed novel by Mario Puzzo, Coppola directs some of the silver screens legends in some of their finest performances. Brando delivers in his most iconic role that will leave you wanting more after the final credits roll. Pacino in what many consider his break out role shows you, the viewer why he will become one of the best performers of a generation, and James Caan delivers in what many consider his finest performance of his career. Spawning two sequels and legions of fans worldwide, this classic has not only held the test of time but remains to this day one of the finest films every created. Anyone who considers themselves a true film buff needs to have seen this timeless classic.

The Godfather is great. For almost thirty years now audiences have been captivated and intrigued by the Corleone family. And no other mafia movie has ever come as close to being this good. The story is just amazing and the directing by Francis Ford Coppola is nothing less than spectacular. Coppola has taken the concept of organized crime in America, something that was once looked down upon, and has built a cult following around it, with Marlon Brando and Al Pacino as their leading figures. And I don't think any single film has produced as many memorable scenes as The Godfather. Who could ever forget Marlon Brando, as Vito Corleone, buying those oranges on that fateful day? Or James Caan, as Sonny Corleone, getting massacred by the barrage of machine-gun bullets? And lines that will forever be repeated by fans like, "I'm gonna make him an offer he can't refuse." The bottom line is that The Godfather has changed the way we look and judge films. It has made cool what is sinful, crime a family value, and dynamic characters the modern-day icons of several generations of storytelling in film. Alongside all the revolutionary pictures of all time, The Godfather earns it place at the very top. Whether it is the #3 greatest film by the American Film Institute, #1 by IMDb, or #2 by me, this movie should very well be agreed by all to be a landmark in American film history.

After spending three hours to watch the film, I think it was a good way to study violence, power and honor. Also the justice and crime in America. One of the center of the story is "family". In the film, there is one sentence"A man who doesn't spend time with his family can never be a real man.". Family is always the best support. I think one of the reasons of the success of the Corleone's business is their good relationship of the family. every time they did their job, they have a good plan. The movie has the best actors, they can show the characteristic of the character, the whispering of Marlon Brando(the godfather), the smart and wise of Al Pacino(Michael), the stable of Robert Duvall(Tom).. The only weakness of the film is too long, nearly three hours, some of it was quite bore. Anyway, it was one the best movie I have ever seen.

In 1947, a successful banker named Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) is accused of murdering his wife and her lover. Despite his claims of innocence, he is sentenced to life imprisonment and sent to Shawshank Prison. The facility is a harsh and corrupt environment where cruelty and oppression prevail. In Shawshank, Andy forms a close friendship with another inmate, Ellis "Red" Redding (Morgan Freeman), a man who can procure items from the outside. Red becomes a reliable friend to Andy. Using his intelligence and financial expertise, Andy catches the attention of the prison guards and the corrupt warden, eventually managing their financial affairs, which grants him certain privileges. However, Andy is always driven by his desire for freedom and a determination to escape the corrupt system of Shawshank. The film unfolds as a testament to Andy's perseverance and demonstrates how hope can shine even in the darkest of places.

One of the most recommended masterpieces. Highly recommended for someone who loves cinema. The Shawshank Redemption is not just a movie but a profound experience. Its timeless themes, stellar performances, and impeccable storytelling have earned it a rightful place among the greatest films ever made. Whether you watch it for the first time or revisit it, this cinematic gem is sure to leave an indelible mark on your soul. At its heart, The Shawshank Redemption is a film about hope-a rare commodity in the harsh reality of Shawshank Prison, yet one that Andy clings to relentlessly. The final scenes are a testament to the indomitable human spirit, leaving viewers with a sense of fulfillment and optimism that lingers long after the credits roll.
